thread.title: EAGLES GROUNDED: Appalachian State dominates Georgia Southern 31-13
thread.title_full: EAGLES GROUNDED: Appalachian State dominates Georgia Southern 31-13 | savannahnow.com

author: NATHAN DEEN
title: EAGLES GROUNDED: Appalachian State dominates Georgia Southern 31-13
text:
Photos Back | Next Bruce Chapman/The Winston-Salem Journal via AP
Appalachian State defensive back Mondo Williams (4) upends Georgia Southern quarterback Kevin Ellison, left, as Ellison scores a touchdown on Thursday during the first quarter at Kidd Brewer Stadium in Boone, N.C.
Back | Next Bruce Chapman/The Winston-Salem Journal via AP
Appalachian State running back Marcus Cox (14) breaks through the tackle of Georgia Southern defensive end Logan Hunt (91) to score a touchdown.
By NATHAN DEEN
BOONE, N.C. — They came into the game looking like they had all the answers.
Now, after their first Sun Belt Conference loss since they joined the league last season, the Georgia Southern Eagles are left looking for them.
And, of course, that loss came to the team that gave them so much trouble when the Eagles played in the FCS Southern Conference.
Turned out, it was Appalachian State that had all the answers Thursday night at Kidd Brewer Stadium for a GSU offense that had scored 43 or more points in its last five games. The Mountaineers dominated the Eagles 31-13, snapped GSU’s 11-game Sun Belt winning streak and took a big step forward in trying to follow their rivals with a Sun Belt title of their own.
The Mountaineers (6-1, 3-0 Sun Belt) came into the game boasting the nation’s fifth-ranked defense and showed Thursday those numbers weren’t deceiving because of their schedule. Averaging respectable numbers in both rushing and passing defense, they limited the nation’s leading running attack to a season-low 188 yards and never let the Eagles’ passing game get off the ground.
“We ran into a really good team,” Eagles coach Willie Fritz said. “Just a frustrating night. They outplayed us. Give credit to them.”
The Eagles (5-2, 2-1) threw the early punch, uncharacteristically electing to receive the opening kickoff and marching down the field almost unabated for a nine-play 86-yard drive capped by quarterback Kevin Ellison flipping over a defender and into the end zone.
Whatever fire the Eagles had was extinguished by a Mountaineer defense that attacked the ball and almost seemed to know what was coming. The Eagles gained just 29 yards of offense from that point until halftime. Junior running back Matt Breida was limited to 78 yards on 14 carries, about 5 yards below his season yards per carry average of 10.3.
“We felt good about things after our first series,” Fritz said. “Guys just never stayed on schedule throughout the game. A loss here, a minus-play there. We weren’t in good down-and-distance situations.”
The Mountaineers, meanwhile, kept the GSU defense off balance by mixing up the play calling. Taking advantage of good field position, Marcus Cox gave the Mountaineers the lead early in the second quarter by slicing through the defense to an 18-yard touchdown run.
The next drive, ASU sophomore quarterback Taylor Lamb hit Cox, who was left alone coming out of the backfield, for a 30-yard pass play. Two plays later, Lamb hit Simms McElfresh in the back of the end zone on a rollout, giving App State a 10-point lead. Lamb later hit tight end Barrett Burns for a 33-yard TD in the second half and finished 14 of 20 for 202 yards and two touchdowns. Cox gained 96 yards on 21 carries with two scores.
The Eagles missed their opportunity to maybe change the direction of the game after forcing App State to a three-and-out to start the third quarter. GSU ran a perfectly called play-action pass on its next drive, and Myles Campbell streaked downfield uncovered, but Ellison’s throw caused Campbell to make a tough adjustment, allowing a Mountaineer to catch up and make the tackle.
“That was an opportunity to get a touchdown,” Fritz said. “A touchdown and we’re right back in the game with a lot of conference.”
The gain got the Eagles 28 yards to the ASU 14-yard line, but they went nowhere from there, and Alex Hanks missed a 35-yard field-goal attempt.
All night, the App State defense took away the GSU running game on first down and forced the Eagles into passing situations. It paid off in the third quarter when Kevin Ellison threw an interception to Mondo Williams.
Backup quarterback Favian Upshaw couldn’t do anything to lift the GSU passing game. He missed on three attempts when he came in for a series in the fourth quarter, including an interception. The Mountaineers then bled the clock on a 13-play drive that lasted over seven minutes and ended with a 6-yard scoring run by Cox.
The Eagles finally scored a meaningless touchdown in the fourth quarter when LA Ramsby ran for a 19-yard touchdown.
Dobson kept out
GSU senior safety Matt Dobson did not play in Thursday’s game after sustaining an ankle injury in Saturday’s 56-26 win against New Mexico State.
Fritz said Dobson could have played in the second half after the win if the Eagles needed him, but injury appears to have been more complicated than expected. Linebackers Ironhead Gallon and William Bussey were also sorely missed in the first half, having to sit out as a result of being called for targeting in the second half against New Mexico State.
